title: AT&T's stock surges after profit beat, capital allocation plans offset revenue miss
text: Shares of AT&T Inc. T, +0.24% surged 1.9% in premarket trading Monday, after the media and communications giant beat third-quarter profit expectations and provided a 3-year capital allocation plan with help from activist investor Elliott Management, but missed on revenue. Net income fell to $3.70 billion, or 50 cents a share, from $4.72 billion, or 65 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding non-recurring items, adjusted earnings per share came to 94 cents, above the FactSet consensus of 93 cents. Revenue fell 2.5% to $44.59 billion, below the FactSet consensus of $45.11 billion. Communications revenue fell 1.7% to $35.4 billion to miss expectations of $35.75 billion and WarnerMedia revenue, which includes HBO, declined 4.4% to $7.8 billion to miss expectations of $8.18 billion. The company expects 2020 adjusted EPS of $3.60 to $3.70, compared with the FactSet consensus of $3.63. The company provided a 3-year capital allocation plan, including continued modest dividend growth, debt reduction and share repurchases. "The objectives we have outlined today have been central to our plans for many months, even before we closed our acquisition of Time Warner," said Chief Executive Randall Stephenson. "I've found our engagement with Elliott to be constructive and helpful, and I look forward to continuing those conversations." AT&T's stock has rallied 8.1% over the past three months through Friday, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +0.57% has slipped 0.9%.
